Answer: The code you provided is already set up to display a confirmation dialog before sending an SMS. The dialog is created using AlertDialog.Builder and displayed using dlg.show(). The dialog has two buttons: "Yes" and "Cancel". If the user clicks "Yes", the SMS is sent using SmsManager. If the user clicks "Cancel", the dialog is cancelled.

If you want the dialog to stay until the user clicks "Yes" or "Cancel", you can modify the code to use a while loop. Here's an example of how you can do this:

```java
public void send_SMS(final String message) {
    try {
        AlertDialog.Builder dialog = new AlertDialog.Builder(ctx);
        dialog.setTitle("Send SMS");
        dialog.setMessage("Are U sure want to Send SMS");
        dialog.setCancelable(false); // Set this to false to make the dialog stay until the user clicks "Yes" or "Cancel"
        dialog.setPositiveButton("Yes", new DialogInterface.OnClickListener() {
            @Override
            public void onClick(DialogInterface dialog, int which) {
                // TODO Auto-generated method stub
                sentpi = PendingIntent.getBroadcast(ctx, 0, new Intent(SENT), 0);
                delpi = PendingIntent.getBroadcast(ctx, 0, new Intent(DELIVERED), 0);
                // Rest of your code...
            }
        });
        dialog.setNegativeButton("Cancel", new DialogInterface.OnClickListener() {
            @Override
            public void onClick(DialogInterface dialog, int which) {
                // TODO Auto-generated method stub
                dialog.cancel();
            }
        });
        AlertDialog dlg = dialog.create();
        dlg.show();

        // Use a while loop to keep the dialog displayed until the user clicks "Yes" or "Cancel"
        while (dlg.isShowing()) {
            // Do nothing, just wait for the user to click "Yes" or "Cancel"
        }
    } catch (Throwable e) {
        dlg = new ExceptionDialog(this.ctx, "Sending SMS", e.getMessage());
        dlg.show();
    }
}
```

In this modified code, the dialog is set to not be cancelable (dialog.setCancelable(false)) and a while loop is used to keep the dialog displayed until the user clicks "Yes" or "Cancel". The loop does nothing, just waits for the user to click one of the buttons. Once the user clicks "Yes" or "Cancel", the dialog will close and the rest of your code will continue to execute.

Please note that this solution will block the main thread, so you should consider using an AsyncTask or a separate thread if you need to perform other operations while the dialog is displayed.
